question_text: In generative syntax, what is a theta role?
correct_answer: A semantic role such as agent, patient, or theme assigned by a predicate to each of its arguments.
distractors: A syntactic position in the phrase structure tree that determines the linear order of constituents.
A morphological feature such as tense, person, or number checked during syntactic derivation.
A phonological rule that governs the stress pattern assigned to words within a sentence.

question_text: What does the head-directionality parameter classify in languages?
correct_answer: Whether the head of a phrase precedes its complements (head-initial) or follows them (head-final).
distractors: Whether a language marks grammatical relations through word order or through morphological case inflection.
Whether subjects must appear before the verb or can freely occur in postverbal position.
Whether functional categories like tense and agreement are realized as prefixes or as suffixes.

question_text: What does the VP-internal subject hypothesis propose about where subjects originate?
correct_answer: Subjects are base-generated inside the verb phrase and later move to the specifier of TP.
distractors: Subjects are merged directly into the specifier of CP and remain there throughout the derivation.
Subjects originate in an adjunct position outside the clause and are licensed by discourse context.
Subjects are base-generated in the specifier of TP and assign their theta role from that position.

question_text: What did Pollock's split INFL hypothesis propose about the structure of the inflectional phrase?
correct_answer: It split the single INFL node into separate functional projections for tense (TP) and agreement (AgrP).
distractors: It merged all inflectional features into a single head to simplify the number of functional projections.
It eliminated the inflectional phrase entirely and distributed its features across lexical verb projections.
It replaced the inflectional phrase with a complementizer phrase that hosts both tense and agreement.

correct_answer: It allows the subject pronoun to be omitted when it is recoverable from verbal morphology or context.
distractors: It requires every finite clause to contain an overt subject even when the referent is pragmatically clear.
It permits the verb to be dropped from a sentence whenever the predicate is inferable from discourse.
It allows object noun phrases to be deleted freely regardless of the richness of verbal inflection.

question_text: In syntax, what are island constraints?
correct_answer: Restrictions that block syntactic movement of constituents out of certain structural domains.
distractors: Requirements that every moved constituent must leave a phonologically visible copy in its base position.
Conditions that permit free extraction of any element as long as it lands in a specifier position.
Principles that determine the linear ordering of words within a single phrase structure projection.

question_text: In Government and Binding theory, what does control theory govern?
correct_answer: The interpretation of the null subject PRO in infinitival and other nonfinite complement clauses.
distractors: The assignment of structural case to overt noun phrases by finite tense heads and transitive verbs.
The distribution of reflexive pronouns and their requirement to be bound within a local domain.
The licensing of empty operator chains created by topicalization and focus movement operations.

question_text: In Government and Binding theory, what is the syntactic relation of government?
correct_answer: A structural relation in which a head licenses properties of a dependent element it m-commands without barriers intervening.
distractors: A linear adjacency relation requiring that a dependent element appear immediately next to its selecting head.
A semantic relation in which a predicate assigns a thematic role to an argument in its specifier position.
A discourse relation in which a topic phrase binds a pronoun located in the comment portion of the sentence.

question_text: What is the central structure-building operation in Chomsky's Minimalist Program?
correct_answer: Merge, which combines two syntactic objects to form a new set and applies recursively to its own output.
distractors: Adjunction, which attaches modifiers to maximal projections without altering the label of the host phrase.
Government, which establishes a licensing relation between a head and the elements it c-commands locally.
Spell-Out, which transfers completed syntactic structures to the phonological and semantic interfaces simultaneously.

question_text: In Minimalist syntax, what does the Phase Impenetrability Condition state?
correct_answer: Once a phase is complete, its internal domain is transferred to the interfaces and becomes inaccessible to further syntactic operations.
distractors: All features within a syntactic phase must be checked before any lexical items from the numeration can be merged.
Movement out of any clause boundary is universally prohibited unless the moved element carries an EPP feature.
Each phase head must agree with every goal in its c-command domain before the derivation can continue upward.
